source_utterance_info.reason: The utterance uses a Korean phrase to describe an activity. The English correction uses the pattern 'I haven't been doing [activity]'.

selected_error.description: Used Korean phrase for describing an activity instead of English pattern.

explanations.introduction: You used the Korean phrase "아무것도 안 해", which translates to "I haven't been doing anything." in English.  Your friend asked, "How about you?" after you heard "How are you doing?" and "I'm doing good."
explanations.main: The error lies in directly translating the Korean phrasing into English.  While "아무것도 안 해" is grammatically correct Korean, English uses a different structure to describe inactivity over a period.  The correct pattern is "I haven't been doing [activity]" or "I haven't been doing anything."  This emphasizes the ongoing nature of the inactivity. For example:  "I haven't been doing much exercise lately." or "I haven't been doing anything fun this week."
explanations.recap: Practice using the English pattern "I haven't been doing [activity]" to express a lack of activity. This will help you sound more natural in English conversations.

problems.target_text: I haven't been doing my homework lately.
He hasn't been doing much exercise recently.

problems.prompt_text: They ____ ____ ____ very well in the competition.
problems.target_text: They haven't been doing very well in the competition.
We haven't been doing anything interesting this week.
She hasn't been doing her best in class.
